'''Elmir''' was, along with [[Ermon]], one of the first two [[Men]] to be [[Awakening of Men|awakened]] at [[Murmenalda]], according to the early [[legendarium]] in some of the outlines for the continuation of ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref name="Mur">{{LT1|X}}, p. 237</ref>

== History ==
[[File:Parma Eldalamberon 10 (back cover).png|thumb|200px|left|''Nuin, Father of Speech'' by [[Tom Loback]]. Art from the back cover of ''[[Parma Eldalamberon 10]]''.]]
Elmir and Ermon were awakened by an [[Elf]] called [[Nuin]], one of the [[Ilkorindi]], who, against the warnings of the wizard [[Tû (king of the Hisildi)|Tû]] his lord, liked to wander far from his home in [[Palisor]] all the way to Murmenalda, and in one of these wanderings he stumbled upon the sleeping bodies of [[Men]], the second children of [[Ilúvatar]].

There, after waking Elmir and Ermon, Nuin taught them speech, and they, alone of all Men, witnessed the [[Sun]] [[The Tale of the Sun and Moon|rising in the West and setting in the East]]; sometime after, the rest of mankind awoke as well, and Nuin, Elmir and Ermon taught ''them'' speech in return - and the race of Men "grew in stature, and gathered knowledge of the [[Hisildi|Dark Elves]]".<ref name="Mur"/>

Afterwards, a servant of [[Melko]] called [[Fankil]] turned most Men against the Elves, and in the [[War of Palisor|first war]] between Elves and [[Goblins]], it is said that ''only'' the people of Ermon fought on the side of the Elves,<ref name="Mur"/> possibly implying that, either Elmir and his folk fought on the side of Melko, or that Elmir died before the war.

Ultimately, however, Elmir's fate is unknown.

== Etymology ==
The name ''Elmir'' might be in [[Ilkorin]], according to [[Christopher Gilson]], but its meaning is unclear.<ref>[[Christopher Gilson]], "His Breath Was Taken Away: Tolkien, Barfield, and Elvish Diction", in {{TS|14}}, p. 37</ref>
